Description: Joining fragments of a pottery ampulla (flask) with round body and two handles. On side (a), within a border of small studs, Saint Menas stands frontally, his arms outstretched in blessing. Above each arm is a group of four studs arranged as a cross. He wears a short tunic and a long cloak. Camels flank him. Side (b) is missing, but would normally show a a sailing ship. Calcaric marl orange clay with a buff surface, large white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Close parallels acquired by the British Museum (Bailey 2008, 3418; Dalton 1901, 883; Buckton 1994, 124), from Alexandria (Dutilh 1904: pls 1 and 2, fig. 22; Yoyotte 1997: no. 256), dated fifth to mid-seventh century AD (Witt 2000, no. 22).
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (IE.13) (Phase 3)
